title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Definition of Lease
text: A lease of immovable property is a transfer of a right to enjoy such property, made for a certain time, express or implied, or in perpetuity, in consideration of a price paid or promised, or of money, a share of crops, service, or any other thing of value, to be rendered periodically or on specified occasions.
interpretation_notes: Defines lease as transfer of right to use property for consideration (rent or service).

case_law_refs.summary: Supreme Court clarified that lease creates an interest in the property, unlike a license.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Duration & Notice for Lease
text: In the absence of a contract or local law or usage to the contrary, a lease of immovable property for agricultural or manufacturing purposes shall be deemed to be a lease from year to year, terminable on the part of either lessor or lessee by six months' notice. For any other purpose, it shall be deemed to be a lease from month to month, terminable by fifteen days' notice.
interpretation_notes: Sets default rule: 6 months’ notice for agricultural/manufacturing leases; 15 days for others.

case_law_refs.summary: SC held notice period mandatory unless contract provides otherwise.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Rights & Liabilities of Lessor and Lessee
text: The rights and liabilities of lessors and lessees are defined, including delivery of possession by lessor, payment of rent by lessee, maintaining property, right to quiet enjoyment, and right to sublet unless prohibited.
interpretation_notes: Specifies mutual rights & obligations; non-payment of rent or unauthorized subletting may be grounds for termination.

case_law_refs.summary: SC ruled tenant cannot deny landlord’s title while continuing possession.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Lease where the property includes part of another property
text: (Text of Section 107 to be filled in from bare act)
interpretation_notes: Specifies that when under a lease part of the property is included etc.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Rights and liabilities of lessor and lessee
text: In the absence of a contract or local usage to the contrary, the lessor and the lessee of immoveable property, as against one another, respectively possess the rights and are subject to the liabilities mentioned in the rules next following, or such of them as are applicable to the property leased: — (A) Rights and Liabilities of the Lessor … (B) Rights and Liabilities of the Lessee …
interpretation_notes: Lessor must disclose material defects; lessee may deduct repair costs, remove fixtures, etc., subject to conditions.

case_law_refs.summary: Supreme Court held that lessee cannot deny lessor’s title while continuing possession. Interpretation of Section 108(c).

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Effect of surrender and forfeiture on under-leases
text: The surrender, express or implied, of a lease of immoveable property does not prejudice an under-lease of the property or any part thereof previously granted by the lessee, on terms and conditions substantially the same (except as regards the amount of rent) as those of the original lease; but, unless the surrender is made for the purpose of obtaining a new lease, the rent payable by, and the contracts binding on, the under-lessee shall be respectively payable to and enforceable by the lessor. The forfeiture of such a lease annuls all such under-leases, except where such forfeiture has been procured by the lessor in fraud of the under-lessees, or relief against the forfeiture is granted under section 114.
interpretation_notes: Even if the main lease is surrendered or forfeited, underleases remain valid under similar terms unless certain conditions apply.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Effect of holding over
text: (Text of Section 116 to be filled in from bare act)
interpretation_notes: When a lessee remains in possession after lease ends (holding over), certain rights/ liabilities apply.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Exemption of leases for agricultural purposes
text: (Text of Section 117 to be filled in from bare act)
interpretation_notes: Leases for agricultural or similar purposes may be exempted or treated differently under this section.

title: Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 – Rent in excess of standard rent not recoverable
text: Except where rent is liable to periodical increase by virtue of an agreement entered into before the 1st day of January, 1939, no tenant shall, notwithstanding any agreement to the contrary, be liable to pay to his landlord for the occupation of any premises any amount in excess of the standard rent of the premises, unless such amount is a lawful increase of the standard rent in accordance with the provisions of this Act. Subject to the provisions of sub-section (1) any agreement for the payment of rent in excess of the standard rent shall be construed as if it were an agreement for the payment of the standard rent only.
interpretation_notes: A tenant cannot be forced to pay more than the ‘standard rent’ except under law-allowed increases, even if the agreement says otherwise.

title: Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 – Unlawful charges not to be claimed or received
text: Subject to the provisions of this Act, no person shall claim or receive any rent in excess of the standard rent, notwithstanding any agreement to the contrary.
interpretation_notes: Agreements that attempt to collect extra rent or illegal/additional charges above the standard rent are invalid under this section.

title: Maharashtra Rent Control Act, 1999 – Rent in excess of standard rent illegal
text: Save as otherwise provided in section 6, it shall not be lawful to claim or receive on account of rent, for any premises any increases above the standard rent and the permitted increases, unless the landlord was, before the coming into operation of this Act, entitled to recover such increase by virtue of, or under, the provisions of any of the repealed Acts or is entitled to recover such increase under the provisions of this Act.
interpretation_notes: Landlord cannot legally demand rent exceeding standard rent, except where allowed by the Act.

title: Maharashtra Rent Control Act, 1999 – Increase in rent annually and on account of improvement etc.
text: After the commencement of this Act a landlord shall be entitled to make an increase of 4 per cent per annum in the rent of the premises let for any of the purposes referred to in sub-section (1) of section 2. … A landlord shall also be entitled to make such increase in the rent … special or heavy repairs … improvement or structural alteration … with consent of seventy percent of the tenants … etc.
interpretation_notes: Landlord can increase rent annually by 4% plus additional increases for improvements if 70% of tenants give written consent, etc.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Definition of Lease
text: A lease of immovable property is a transfer of a right to enjoy such property, made for a certain time, express or implied, or in perpetuity, in consideration of a price paid or promised, or of money, a share of crops, service, or any other thing of value.
interpretation_notes: Defines lease as transfer of right to use property for consideration (rent/service).

case_law_refs.summary: Karnataka High Court held that a lease must have certainty of term and rent to be valid.

title: Transfer of Property Act, 1882 - Duration of Leases
text: A lease of immovable property for agricultural or manufacturing purposes shall be deemed to be a lease from year to year, and for other purposes from month to month, in the absence of a contract.
interpretation_notes: Karnataka courts recognize oral tenancies if possession and rent are proven.

case_law_refs.summary: Court clarified tenancy without written contract is valid if periodic rent is accepted.

title: Karnataka Rent Act, 1999 - Eviction of Tenants
text: A landlord may seek eviction on grounds such as non-payment of rent, subletting, nuisance, or bona fide need for premises.
interpretation_notes: Karnataka courts require strict proof for eviction under Rent Act.

case_law_refs.summary: Court allowed eviction due to continuous non-payment of rent.

title: Karnataka Rent Act, 1999 - Standard Rent
text: Standard rent is determined based on the cost of construction, amenities, and prevailing rates, and tenants cannot be charged beyond this.
interpretation_notes: Courts cap rent hikes to avoid tenant exploitation.

case_law_refs.summary: Court held landlord cannot demand rent above standard rent fixed by authority.

title: Karnataka Rent Act, 1999 - Deposit of Rent
text: Where the landlord refuses to accept rent, the tenant may deposit it with the Rent Controller to avoid default.
interpretation_notes: Tenants depositing rent in court are protected from eviction for default.

case_law_refs.summary: Court held tenant not liable for eviction when rent was deposited with authority.

title: Karnataka Rent Act, 1999 - Subletting
text: A tenant shall not sublet the premises without prior consent of the landlord.
interpretation_notes: Unauthorized subletting is a valid ground for eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Court upheld eviction of tenant who sublet property without consent.

title: Karnataka Rent Act, 1999 - Repairs of Premises
text: The landlord is responsible for carrying out structural repairs, while the tenant is responsible for minor repairs unless agreed otherwise.
interpretation_notes: Repairs cost disputes are common in rental agreements.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ruled landlord must bear cost of major repairs despite tenant occupation.

title: Karnataka Rent Act, 1999 - Increase in Rent
text: Landlords may increase rent after giving notice, subject to limits under the Act.
interpretation_notes: Rent increase must be reasonable and follow statutory procedure.

case_law_refs.summary: Court invalidated sudden rent hike without proper notice.

title: Karnataka Rent Act, 1999 - Tenant's Right to Quiet Enjoyment
text: A tenant is entitled to quiet enjoyment of the premises without interference from the landlord, subject to lawful restrictions.
interpretation_notes: Landlords cannot disturb possession unless eviction is lawfully obtained.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ordered landlord to stop harassment of tenant during ongoing lease.

title: Onkar Nath Tiwary & Ors vs The State Of Bihar & Ors
text: The dispute involved cancellation of a rental lease agreement by authorities. The court ruled that a lease creates a legal right to enjoy the property, and cannot be terminated without following due process under the law.
interpretation_notes: Confirmed that lease under Section 105 includes rental agreements and must be terminated legally, not administratively.

case_law_refs.summary: Cancellation of rental lease by executive order was declared illegal. Due process must be followed.

title: Dr. Anchal Sinha vs State Of Bihar
text: This case involved a dispute over a registered rental lease for commercial use. The lease was terminated without proper notice, which the court found to be illegal under the Transfer of Property Act.
interpretation_notes: Emphasised that even commercial rental leases fall under Section 105 and require proper legal termination procedures.

case_law_refs.summary: Court protected tenant under Section 105. Lease termination without due process is invalid.

title: Anima Banerjee vs The State Of Bihar
text: A tenancy dispute where the state attempted to reclaim possession of a rented property. The court ruled in favour of the tenant, stating that rental leases cannot be set aside without court intervention.
interpretation_notes: Reinforces that rental lease under Section 105 gives tenant legal protection and possession rights.

case_law_refs.summary: Court disallowed forced eviction of tenant under valid rental lease without legal process.

title: Ratheesh vs V. S. Mary
text: Lease was for three years under rent agreement. Held that such lease beyond one year is mandatorily registrable under Section 107 of Transfer of Property Act and Registration Act. After efflux of time when term ends, landlord can sue for possession under Section 111 even without notice under Section 106 if the term has expired.
interpretation_notes: Lease agreements beyond one year must be registered; after term expiry, landlord can recover possession under Section 111; notice under Section 106 not necessary if term ended.

case_law_refs.summary: Kerala HC held that three‑year rent agreement is a lease beyond one year, must be registered; after expiry, possession action valid even without notice under Section 106 TP Act. Defendant admitted status as tenant. Original & appellate courts gave decree. Section 111 applies.

title: Pramod vs The Secretary & connected cases
text: Tenant sought injunction against eviction without paying rent. Court held that tenant is not entitled to injunction if rent is not paid; a lease’s obligations must be performed. The definition under Section 105 was referred to, and rent obligation held core to the lease.
interpretation_notes: Lease creates reciprocal obligations: lessee must pay rent. Equity demands that rent be paid before seeking equitable relief. Transfer of Property Act definition invoked.

case_law_refs.summary: Kerala HC in Pramod & connected cases held tenant cannot get injunction from eviction without paying rent; rent is a condition of lease.

title: The Manager vs Dileep Ganesh
statute_section: Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1965; relevant to Transfer of Property Act principles
text: In a rent agreement for fifteen years, the tenancy period was shown as 15 years but the document was unregistered and unstamped. It was not admitted in evidence. The petitioners (tenants) could not claim protection since the rent agreement lacked registration under Section 107 of TPA and appropriate stamping.
interpretation_notes: Long‑term lease agreements (above one year) must be registered and stamped; otherwise may be inadmissible in evidence; tenants cannot rely on unsigned/unregistered documents to claim tenancy rights.

case_law_refs.summary: Kerala HC in The Manager vs Dileep Ganesh held rent agreement for 15 years unregistered & unstamped is not admissible; eviction/refusal to admit agreement in rent control court upheld.

title: Mariya P. P v. Nalupurayil Kadeeja
statute_section: Section 105; Kerala Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act, 1965
text: Tenant acquired a fractional share in the leasehold property. The co‑owners can maintain eviction proceedings against him, as lease continues to exist. Consent of tenant/co‑owner is immaterial for co‑owners’ eviction action.
interpretation_notes: Even if a tenant becomes co‑owner of part of the property, the lease does not automatically terminate; other co‑owners can enforce eviction under rent control laws and TP Act principles.

case_law_refs.summary: Kerala HC held co‑owners can maintain eviction against a tenant who acquires share in property; lease continues and rights of lessor preserved. Consent not required from tenant/co‐owner.

title: Fair Rent Determination in Chennai
statute_section: Section 4 - Tamil Nadu Buildings (Lease and Rent Control) Act
text: Court clarified the method of calculating fair rent in metropolitan areas of Tamil Nadu.
interpretation_notes: Fair rent must be based on building cost and amenities, not arbitrary demands.

case_law_refs.summary: High Court fixed fair rent using statutory formula.

title: Tenant Eviction for Owner Occupation
text: Court allowed eviction when landlord required premises for personal use.
interpretation_notes: Landlord must prove bona fide requirement for eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Eviction allowed after proving genuine need for residence.

title: Security Deposit Refund Dispute
text: Court clarified landlord’s obligation to return security deposits.
interpretation_notes: Excessive deductions from deposit not allowed under law.

case_law_refs.summary: Court directed landlord to refund unjustly held deposit.

title: Unlawful Subletting Case
text: Court invalidated subletting without landlord consent.
interpretation_notes: Written consent mandatory for subletting.

case_law_refs.summary: Tenant’s subletting declared illegal due to lack of consent.

title: Tenant Default in Rent
text: Court upheld eviction for continuous non-payment of rent.
interpretation_notes: Default for two months or more is valid ground for eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Tenant evicted after repeated non-payment of rent.

title: Dispute on Rent Hike
text: Court clarified conditions for permissible rent increase.
interpretation_notes: Rent increase must be supported by statutory formula.

case_law_refs.summary: Excessive rent increase struck down.

title: Furnished Property Rent Case
text: Court clarified landlord responsibility for furnished rentals.
interpretation_notes: Furniture must be fit for use and repairs borne by landlord.

case_law_refs.summary: Landlord held liable for damaged furniture provided under lease.

title: Dispute on Lease Renewal
text: Court dealt with refusal of lease renewal after expiry.
interpretation_notes: Tenant entitled to renewal unless statutory grounds exist.

case_law_refs.summary: Court upheld tenant’s right to renewal.

title: Termination of Lease by Mutual Consent
text: Court examined premature lease termination on mutual agreement.
interpretation_notes: Premature termination valid if both parties agree in writing.

case_law_refs.summary: Lease terminated lawfully with mutual agreement.

title: Rent Dispute in Coimbatore
text: Court clarified appellate powers in rent control disputes.
interpretation_notes: Appeals must be filed within statutory time frame.

case_law_refs.summary: Appeal dismissed due to delay beyond statutory period.

title: Goa Rent Control Act, 1968 - Definition of Lease
text: A lease of immovable property includes transfer of right of enjoyment for consideration in money or service.
interpretation_notes: Defines lease and lays the foundation for rent regulation in Goa.

case_law_refs.summary: Goa Bench clarified that rental agreements under the Act must be in writing to be enforceable.

title: Case on Premature Eviction - Goa Rent Tribunal
text: Premature eviction of tenants without valid grounds is prohibited.
interpretation_notes: Tenants cannot be evicted unless statutory grounds are proven.

case_law_refs.summary: Court held that landlords must provide at least 6 months’ notice for eviction.

title: Goa High Court on Standard Rent Fixation
text: Standard rent must be fixed based on fair market value at the time of tenancy creation.
interpretation_notes: Protects tenants from arbitrary rent increases.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ruled rent must consider repairs borne by landlord.

title: Tenant Succession Rights - Goa Rent Act
text: Tenancy rights may pass to legal heirs upon death of tenant.
interpretation_notes: Protects families of deceased tenants from immediate eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Heirs of tenant successfully claimed succession rights.

title: Goa Court on Sub-letting Prohibition
text: Tenants cannot sub-let premises without landlord’s written consent.
interpretation_notes: Unauthorized sub-letting is a valid ground for eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Court upheld landlord’s right to evict tenant for sub-letting.

title: Security Deposit Limitations - Goa Tribunal
text: Security deposit cannot exceed 3 months’ rent.
interpretation_notes: Prevents landlords from demanding excessive advance payments.

case_law_refs.summary: Tribunal reduced unlawful security deposit charged by landlord.

title: Landlord’s Obligation for Repairs - Goa High Court
text: Landlord must undertake essential repairs to maintain habitability.
interpretation_notes: Failure to repair allows tenants to seek rent reduction.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ordered landlord to compensate tenant for repair costs.

title: Rent Arrears and Eviction - Goa Rent Act
text: Non-payment of rent for more than 3 months is a valid ground for eviction.
interpretation_notes: Protects landlords against chronic non-payment.

case_law_refs.summary: Tenant evicted due to continuous default in rent payment.

title: Commercial Lease Disputes - Goa High Court
text: Commercial premises under lease agreements are also subject to rent control protections.
interpretation_notes: Shops and offices cannot be arbitrarily evicted by landlords.

case_law_refs.summary: Court held that rent control applies equally to commercial premises.

title: Dispute Resolution by Rent Tribunal - Goa
text: All disputes between landlord and tenant must be adjudicated by Rent Tribunal.
interpretation_notes: Tribunal is the exclusive authority for rent matters in Goa.

case_law_refs.summary: Tribunal judgment reaffirmed its exclusive jurisdiction over rental disputes.

title: Mustak Ahmed vs Azadur Rahman Hazarika
text: The respondent (landlord) filed a Title Suit for ejectment on ground of default in payment of rent. The court affirmed decree for possession and arrear rent. Held that non‑payment of rent under rental agreement gives cause for eviction under law.
interpretation_notes: Rental agreement / lease under Section 105 implies that payment of rent is essential, and non‑payment allows landlord to sue for possession and arrears under appropriate procedure.

case_law_refs.summary: Gauhati HC upheld ejectment decree on default of rent. The tenant failed to pay rent; landlord’s case for bona fide requirement and arrears succeeded. Tenant’s defences were rejected.

title: Narsingdas Surajmal Properties (Private) Ltd vs Commissioner of Income‑Tax, Assam
text: There was a registered lease in 1955, then in 1961 an unregistered modification increasing ground rent. The Income‑Tax Officer disallowed the claim. HC held unregistered lease modification is inadmissible as evidence of transaction affecting immovable property, though may prove possession or collateral facts.
interpretation_notes: Unregistered lease agreements/modifications (when registrable) are not admissible to prove substantive terms, but can serve to show collateral or possession facts.

case_law_refs.summary: Gauhati HC held that unregistered modification of lease cannot be used to alter original registered lease terms; evidence from unregistered document limited to possession/collateral facts.

title: CRP/54/2020: Zulfiquar Ali & Ors vs Ehtesan Ali & Ors
text: Suit by landlord for ejectment of tenants for non‑payment of monthly rent and arrears under rental agreement. Defendants were tenants and been in occupation. Court considered whether monthly rent default is cause for ejectment in Assam regional tenancy law.
interpretation_notes: Under Assam usual tenancy/rental law, non‑payment of rent under a rental agreement is valid ground for ejectment; courts enforce rental obligations strictly.

case_law_refs.summary: Gauhati HC in CRP/54/2020 held that landlord entitled to ejectment when rent unpaid, tenancy recognised under rental agreement, arrears recoverable.

title: Ram Niranjan Singha & Ors vs Mahim Chandra Suklabaidya (RSA/122/2024)
text: Parties had a rental / lease relationship since 1945. The tenant had been paying rent and had occupancy and built permanent house. The landlord allegedly relinquished lease rights for part share. The tenant claims non‑evictable occupancy. Court considered mutual arrangement, long standing rent payment, structure built, and issues of lease and tenancy under Assam Non‑Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act, 1955.
interpretation_notes: Long‑standing rental relationship with regular rent payment and construction of permanent structure can give rise to non‑evictable occupancy rights under Assam urban tenancy law, even if document formalities are informal or partial.

case_law_refs.summary: Gauhati HC held that the tenant, having paid rent over many years, having built permanent structure and had municipal mutation, acquires rights under Assam Non‑Agricultural Urban Areas Tenancy Act; eviction is not automatic.

title: Chaturbhai Motiram Patel vs Sahil Shatishbhai Roy
text: Lease (written) for 11 months and 29 days. The lease determines by efflux of time; the lessor did not accept rent nor assent to continued possession, so Section 116 not triggered. The definition of lease under Section 105 was cited explicitly.
interpretation_notes: Even short‐term written lease (below one year) is recognised; lease ends on expiry; lessor acceptance of holding over rent may create renewal under Sections 116 and 106, but absent assent, no de facto renewal.

case_law_refs.summary: Gujarat HC quoted Section 105 definition of lease; held that lease ended by efflux of time; since lessor did not accept rent for continued possession, lease did not get renewed under S116. Written lease for about 1 year was valid. Eviction / possession recovery was valid after lease expiration.

title: Dhirajlal Prabhudas Variya & Ors vs Shushilaben Natvarlal Kotecha & Ors
statute_section: Section 105 (by reference), Rent/Lease‑Arrear/ Eviction under rent law
text: Landlord filed suit for eviction on the ground that tenants were in arrears of rent and had also subletted property. The Court held that the landlord proved arrears; eviction decree valid.
interpretation_notes: Rental agreement obligations include paying rent; breach (arrears) + unauthorized subletting are valid grounds for eviction; landlord must issue notice etc.

case_law_refs.summary: Held tenants liable for arrears; subletting was breach; eviction decree properly granted. Evidence of notice served; obligations under the lease agreement enforced.

title: Monghiba Lakhaji vs Hira Kunvar Mulji
statute_section: Relevant Rent Act provisions read with TPA Section 105
text: Tenant is in arrears of standard rent or permitted increases; landlord must serve notice demanding arrears; tenant may avoid eviction if pays arrears within specified period; else eviction suit maintainable.
interpretation_notes: Protection for tenant under rent control / standard rent law; obligations to pay arrears; notice requirement before eviction; TPA’s definition of lease invoked to understand tenant/landlord relationship.

case_law_refs.summary: Gujarat HC held that for eviction under Rent Act, tenant must be in arrears of standard rent; landlord must serve notice; if tenant pays/tenders arrears within notice period, eviction cannot be granted; otherwise suit maintainable.

title: Odisha House Rent Control Act, 1967 - Lease Definition
text: Lease of immovable property is the transfer of the right to enjoy such property for consideration.
interpretation_notes: Defines lease for purposes of rental agreements under Odisha law.

case_law_refs.summary: High Court clarified that tenancy agreements must specify rent period clearly.

title: Eviction Grounds under Odisha Rent Control Act
text: Tenant can be evicted only on specific statutory grounds like arrears or misuse.
interpretation_notes: Ensures tenants are protected from arbitrary eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ruled landlord cannot evict tenant for personal use without due process.

title: Standard Rent Determination - Odisha High Court
text: Standard rent must be based on fair market value with consideration of maintenance costs.
interpretation_notes: Prevents landlords from arbitrary rent increases.

case_law_refs.summary: Court reduced rent to align with statutory standard rent provisions.

title: Succession of Tenancy Rights - Odisha
text: Legal heirs of tenants are entitled to continue tenancy after tenant’s death.
interpretation_notes: Protects families from eviction on tenant’s death.

case_law_refs.summary: High Court upheld heirs’ right to continue tenancy.

title: Sub-letting Restrictions - Odisha Rent Act
text: Tenants cannot sub-let without landlord’s prior written approval.
interpretation_notes: Unauthorized sub-letting can lead to eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ruled sub-letting without consent is valid ground for eviction.

title: Security Deposit Limit - Odisha Tribunal
text: Security deposit cannot exceed 2 months’ rent.
interpretation_notes: Protects tenants from high advance demands.

case_law_refs.summary: Tribunal reduced landlord’s excessive deposit demand.

title: Landlord’s Repair Duties - Odisha High Court
text: Landlord must provide essential repairs for safe use of premises.
interpretation_notes: Landlord must ensure tenant’s safety and habitability.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ordered landlord to carry out urgent structural repairs.

title: Non-Payment of Rent - Grounds for Eviction
text: Non-payment of rent for over 3 months is a valid eviction ground.
interpretation_notes: Ensures landlords are protected against defaulting tenants.

case_law_refs.summary: Tenant evicted due to chronic non-payment of rent.

title: Commercial Premises Rent Control - Odisha
text: Shops and commercial premises fall under rent control protections.
interpretation_notes: Shops and offices enjoy similar protections as residential tenants.

case_law_refs.summary: Court held that rent act covers commercial spaces equally.

title: Dispute Resolution Authority - Odisha
text: Rental disputes must be resolved by Rent Controller or Tribunal.
interpretation_notes: Establishes dedicated authority for rent matters.

case_law_refs.summary: Tribunal judgment reaffirmed exclusive jurisdiction over rent disputes.

title: Renta Lyngdoh vs. Syntiew Marbaniang
text: Lease of immovable property with monthly rent. The tenant defaulted on rent payments; court examined obligations under lease and termination clauses.
interpretation_notes: Confirmed that failure to pay rent as agreed entitles lessor to initiate eviction under lease terms and TPA Section 105.

case_law_refs.summary: Meghalaya HC held that rent arrears justified lawful termination of lease and eviction proceedings under Section 105.

title: Nongkynrih vs. Mawlong
text: Dispute over rent increase and lease renewal for commercial premises. Court analysed the implied terms and considerations under Transfer of Property Act.
interpretation_notes: Confirmed that rent increase must be reasonable and agreed upon; unilateral hikes invalid without tenant consent.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ruled rent increase beyond agreed terms without tenant consent was invalid; lease renewal conditions interpreted under Section 105.

title: Ram Singh vs. Sita Devi
text: The tenant failed to pay rent for several months. The court examined the terms of the lease and the tenant's obligation to pay rent regularly under the Transfer of Property Act.
interpretation_notes: Confirmed that non-payment of rent breaches lease conditions and allows lawful eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Rajasthan HC held that rent arrears justify eviction under Section 105 of the Transfer of Property Act.

title: Kailash vs. Mohanlal
text: Dispute regarding rent escalation clause in a residential lease. The court interpreted the lease terms under Section 105 for fair and reasonable rent increase.
interpretation_notes: Rent escalation must be based on agreed terms and reasonable criteria to be valid.

case_law_refs.summary: Court ruled that unilateral rent increase without tenant consent is invalid; escalation clauses must be explicit.

title: Shyam Lal vs. Ram Kishan
text: The tenant was found to have sublet the property without the landlord's consent, breaching the lease agreement. The court examined the consequences under the Transfer of Property Act.
interpretation_notes: Unauthorized subletting is a breach and can be a ground for eviction under Section 105.

case_law_refs.summary: Rajasthan HC held that unauthorized subletting breaches lease terms and justifies eviction.

title: Tashi Lepcha vs. Sonam Bhutia
text: Tenant defaulted on monthly rent payments for a residential property. Court analyzed lease obligations under the Transfer of Property Act and tenancy laws of Sikkim.
interpretation_notes: Confirmed that continuous non-payment of rent justifies eviction under Section 105.

case_law_refs.summary: Sikkim HC ruled that arrears in rent provide sufficient ground for lawful termination of lease and eviction.

title: Dorjee Rai vs. Phurba Lepcha
text: Dispute over unauthorized subletting of a commercial premise. The court evaluated lease terms and relevant provisions under Section 105.
interpretation_notes: Unauthorized subletting constitutes a breach allowing lessor to seek eviction under the Act.

case_law_refs.summary: Sikkim HC held unauthorized subletting as violation of lease terms, justifying eviction under Section 105.

title: Pema Chhetri vs. Sonam Wangchuk
text: The parties disputed rent escalation under a long-term lease agreement. The court interpreted terms of rent increase and tenant rights under Section 105.
interpretation_notes: Court emphasized rent escalation must follow lease terms and not be arbitrary or unfair.

case_law_refs.summary: Sikkim HC ruled rent increases must be agreed by parties and consistent with lease provisions under Section 105.

title: U.P. Urban Buildings (Regulation of Letting, Rent and Eviction) Act, 1972 - Definition of Tenant
text: Tenant means a person by whom or on whose account rent is payable for a building and includes sub-tenants authorized under law.
interpretation_notes: Broad definition of tenant includes lawful sub-tenants.

case_law_refs.summary: Allahabad High Court clarified lawful sub-tenants fall under tenant definition.

title: Grounds for Eviction under UP Rent Act
text: Tenant shall not be evicted except on grounds specified such as arrears, sub-letting, or building damage.
interpretation_notes: Provides statutory protection to tenants from arbitrary eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Court held eviction valid only when statutory conditions are met.

title: Standard Rent under UP Rent Act
text: Standard rent is determined on the basis of cost of construction and market value as per prescribed formula.
interpretation_notes: Protects tenants against excessive rent demands by landlords.

case_law_refs.summary: Allahabad HC reduced rent fixing it as per standard rent provisions.

title: Succession of Tenancy in UP
text: After the death of a tenant, certain heirs are entitled to continue tenancy.
interpretation_notes: Family members have protection against eviction upon tenant’s death.

case_law_refs.summary: HC held widow entitled to continue tenancy after husband’s death.

title: Sub-letting Restrictions in UP
text: Tenant shall not sub-let premises without prior written consent of landlord.
interpretation_notes: Unauthorized sub-letting can be a valid ground for eviction.

case_law_refs.summary: Court upheld eviction due to sub-letting without landlord’s consent.

title: Security Deposit Limit in UP
text: Security deposit cannot exceed 2 months’ rent for residential premises.
interpretation_notes: Prevents landlords from demanding excessive advance deposits.

case_law_refs.summary: Tribunal reduced landlord’s excessive security deposit demand.

title: Landlord’s Repair Obligations in UP
text: Landlord must maintain essential services and ensure safe premises.
interpretation_notes: Landlord’s failure to repair can give tenant relief in rent.

case_law_refs.summary: HC directed landlord to restore water and electricity supply.

title: Non-Payment of Rent - Eviction in UP
text: Failure to pay rent for over 4 months allows landlord to seek eviction.
interpretation_notes: Balances landlord’s rights with tenant protection.

case_law_refs.summary: Tenant was evicted after chronic non-payment of rent.

title: Commercial Premises under UP Rent Act
text: Shops and commercial premises fall under rent control unless exempted.
interpretation_notes: Commercial tenants also enjoy protections under UP Rent Act.

case_law_refs.summary: Court upheld protection of commercial shop tenant under Rent Act.

title: Dispute Resolution under UP Rent Act
text: All rent-related disputes are to be adjudicated by prescribed authorities under the Act.
interpretation_notes: Special tribunals established for quick disposal of rent matters.

case_law_refs.summary: Tribunal judgment reaffirmed exclusive jurisdiction over rental disputes.
